Introduction

Introducing the Gender Violence Database: Theoretical, Practical, and Pedagogical Challenges of Mapping a Field

In addition to offering a general overview of the Gender Violence Database (GVD for short) as a tool, this paper first traces how our project team has confronted the research-practice divide in the gender violence field that gave rise to our project in the first place—and then the paper offers our project as a model for feminist DH pedagogy.

Overview

The GVD is designed to be a search tool for researchers, practitioners, and the general public looking for relevant research about gender-based violence. Work on the Database began in 2012 as an effort to solve a problem: the gap between the universities producing research on one hand and the growing number of non-profit organizations charged with putting this research into practice on the other—an ever-widening gap between evidence production and evidence-based practice in the field. While non-profit and social service organizations have always relied upon research generated in universities, a shift in emphasis from experiential and grassroots knowledge to professionalization and evidence-based practice over the last two decades has meant that many organizations have had to seek out new sources of information and guidelines for their work.

Unfortunately, many of these same non-profit organizations do not have the resources, personnel, or university connections to secure and take full advantage of such access. If NGOs are expected to use evidence-based practices in providing a safety net for vulnerable populations, they need predictable access to the best available evidence with as few barriers as possible.

Initial Project Development Steps

The GVD team sought to bridge the research-practice gap by rendering the choices that practitioners make in selecting evidence much more precise and useful within the current publishing environment. Central to this goal was the development of a database that (1) offered a consistent set of tags (or keywords) and categories useful for searches across the many disciplines comprising the field of gender violence and (2) facilitated intersectional search strategies that would enable practitioners and researchers to refine their searches to most precisely reflect their current evidentiary needs. In devising every aspect of the project, the GVD team imagined its primary user as a practitioner with time-sensitive, intersectional needs operating under economic and time constraints.

The GVD team first had to determine which topics to include under the “gender violence” umbrella. We ultimately decided to take a comprehensive approach to the field, seeking to include sources that contributed not only to knowledge about discrete acts of violence but to an emerging understanding of the contexts, structures, and precursors of gender violence. The team’s inclusive definition appears in the “About” section of the GVD site:

Our scope includes forms of harm committed on the basis of gender, that are gendered in action, or that reinforce forms of gender oppression already in place. We include research focused on forms of harm such as intimate partner violence, sexual violence, stalking, and trafficking as they affect adults or children in any place in the world. We also include research that addresses the consequences of gender-based violence and that proposes intervention and/or prevention strategies.

Following the socio-ecological model first introduced by Urie Bronfenbrenner and familiar from public health approaches, the GVD team organized the working schema to account for research operating at each of its five levels: intrapersonal factors (knowledge, attitudes, behaviors, and identity characteristics), interpersonal factors (friendships, social networks, family supports, etc.), institutional and organizational factors, community factors, and policy factors (including local, state, federal, and international policies). Using the socio-ecological model to organize tags meant that sources that addressed issues of structural violence and collective oppression could be included in the database alongside more readily familiar forms of gender-based violence.

The next step in building the database was the construction of a working schema—a set of search terms (or key words) applicable to both past and ongoing research in the field. In developing and testing the schema, the team first collected and provisionally tagged scholarly journals explicitly focused on gender-based violence (e.g., Violence Against Women) as well as journals that focused either on gender or violence as primary topics. (Yes, our process has always included reading, and sometimes skimming, all potentially relevant sources one at a time.) Beginning with this set of approximately fifteen journals from across a wide range of disciplines—social work, psychology, criminology, feminist theory, sociology, and medicine chief among them—the team devised a common set of terms and categories that would intelligibly apply across these areas.

The team quickly recognized that a crucial challenge in identifying and synthesizing research across disciplines for both practitioners and researchers is the sheer variety of discipline-specific terms that compete to describe nearly identical contexts, phenomena, or populations. For example, criminology journals most often refer to individuals who have suffered from gender-based violence as “victims,” while other journals in social work and feminist theory refer to this same category of individuals as “survivors.” Within disciplines, too, terms have changed over time in ways that the GVD team aimed to render consistent for users; for example, the term “intimate partner violence” currently describes the phenomenon known in early scholarship as “wife-beating” and that later came to be called “domestic violence.” The GVD team grappled with choices in determining the terms that best represented the current understanding and best practices in the field, at times choosing terms that specific researchers and disciplines did not choose for themselves. Developing this initial schema, a consensus-driven process that lasted a full academic year, meant that the team was engaging in a deliberate and strategic re-mapping of the field of gender violence in the name of multidisciplinary practitioner and researcher access.

In these initial steps, too, the students learned a great deal about the assumptions and conventions of scholarly publishing, including the routine practices of journal editors and contributors that (sometimes inadvertently) contribute to inconsistent terminology and categorization across the field. They learned, for example, that journal contributors themselves are responsible for providing keywords and search terms for their research articles. When there are no standards of consistency for keywords built into the journal’s publishing process, it is quite often the case that these contributors apply terms describing similar populations or phenomena differently even within the same journal issue, so researchers are likely to miss important sources without the steps the team took to ensure cross-disciplinary consistency. The students saw firsthand the utility of their day-to-day work applying the schema tags.

Although we use our working schema as a behind-the-scenes tool, the schema’s organizing principles also structure the primary search apparatus for database users. On the search page, users can either perform a traditional keyword search (which searches titles and abstracts) or choose from an expandable list of hierarchically ordered tags grouped into four general categories: Population (which offers choices of demographic and identity-related factors), Issues (which includes a list of forms of gender-based violence, from the intrapersonal to the political level), Responses (interventions in the published research), and Source Type. Sub-categories nest within larger categories so that users can refine their searches. A second column displays a list of sources that most closely match the current search parameters (beginning with the most recently published matches); from here, users can click on the titles of their search results, view the abstract and publication information, narrow their search for open access articles, and/or generate a tailored annotated bibliography.

It is worth noting that the full list of tags offers users a sense of the multiplicity and complexity of categories available for searches, inviting users to explore research beyond their initial searches and thus quietly teaching them about the scope and depth of gender violence as a field.

Feminist Tool Construction: Intersectional Principles and a Margins-to-Center Approach

It is crucial to highlight that feminist principles have guided the day-to-day work of decision making and workflow since the project’s beginning and help make this project a model for feminist DH pedagogy.

First, in devising and curating the schema terms, the GVD team prioritized intersectional principles at every stage of decision-making. Intersectionality—the understanding that individuals possess interlocking identities (of race, class, gender, sexual orientation, ability status, etc.) that render individuals differently vulnerable to structures of oppression—shapes both the lived experiences of people impacted by violence and the interventions and practices designed to prevent violence and support survivors. An intersectional approach depends upon understanding how an individual’s identities may work in concert to create barriers or opportunities for effective intervention; so, for example, a survivor of sexual violence who is an undocumented immigrant and a legal minor will likely require different forms of intervention than a white lesbian citizen survivor of sexual assault on, say, a college campus. Searches work best if the search terms themselves are flexible and responsive to such interlocking identities and contexts. Rather than using tags that would combine multiple identities—“lesbian survivors of child abuse”—as many publications do, the GVD team assigns tags that break down identity markers into the smallest possible categories so that users can run searches that recombine each of those categories in nuanced and productive ways.

Intersectional approaches are crucial in a field where both research and practice have historically prioritized normative populations to the detriment of groups and individuals who are most vulnerable to multiple forms of violence as a consequence of their current and historical oppression and marginalization. With its most visible contemporary origins in second-wave feminist activism in the 1970s and 80s, Gender Violence as a scholarly field has only relatively recently begun to move beyond a disproportionate focus on white, cisgender heterosexual female survivors to investigate the compounding vulnerabilities most survivors face. Providing tags that allow for nuanced, intersectional searches remains a priority for the team; in practice contexts, the need for new information, innovative interventions, or deeper understanding about underrepresented populations are likely scenarios that prompt time-sensitive literature searches. It is essential, then, for any tool to provide accessible ways to move beyond normative searches to include a wide range of identities and contexts.

bell hooks’ margin-to-center approach further informed the GVD team’s intersectional principles of schema development. This approach begins scholarly and activist investigation with a focus on historically marginalized populations—on individuals and groups that possess the most interlocking oppressed identities; the margin, rather than the center, then, becomes the starting point for theoretical and practical interventions aimed at dismantling seemingly intractable systemic problems like gender-based violence. Implicit in this approach is the assumption that interventions that are truly effective for marginalized populations will almost inevitably also be effective (or easier to adapt) for those in the center, who face far fewer challenges. By contrast, the converse approach—beginning with the normative center and working outward toward the margins (which entails ad hoc incorporation of contextual complexity and identity-based vulnerabilities) has historically been ineffective and exclusionary. Addressing the much more complicated experiences of those on the margins demands a nuanced attention to contexts and structures that create layers of heightened vulnerability to violence on one hand—and serious barriers to access to services and support on the other.

Feminist Pedagogical Principles

In addition to its intersectional feminist approach to research curation, the GVD student team also consistently engages in feminist practice and pedagogical engagement. Weekly meetings are highly collaborative and emphasize the expertise of students in the weeds of the research: these meetings begin with reports on innovations in the field, and subsequent conversations regularly focus on topics that include the conventions of journal publishing, the tensions among disciplines that differently define problems, populations, and interventions, the role of users and usability studies in site design, and the challenges of ethically applying labels to people, phenomena, and scholarship genres. Following feminist principles, almost every decision about the database—the process for including new tags to the schema, the design of the logo and interface, the inclusion or exclusion of sources, the protocols for usability studies, etc.—happens by consensus. In addition, students also write blog posts about their particular contributions to the project for publication on the GVD website; many of these posts highlight students’ reflections on the state of the research as well as on the ethical and feminist challenges they have encountered in database construction.

Schema Development and Evolution: New Tags for New Times

One example of feminist engagement among the student team is the group-generated process for introducing new tags to the existing schema. Even though we took great care in the project’s initial stages to create a schema that reflected the state of this multidisciplinary field, it was inevitable that new topics and areas of study continue to emerge in the scholarship—fields of study evolve, after all—and we had to develop a process for incorporating them.

Because GVD team members read through each article before adding it to the database, they observe firsthand new trends surfacing in the scholarship. Additionally, team members typically engage with articles in chronological order, which primes them to notice when new topics emerge and which topics stay relevant to the scholarship. When themes not yet included in the schema emerge in multiple articles across issues of a journal and/or in a variety of journals, team members propose the need for a new tag to the whole GVD team in one of the regular weekly group discussions.

Given the volume of articles already in the database—right now, approaching 15,000 sources and growing—adding a tag is a serious matter; a new tag in the schema means going back through all previous sources already in the database to make sure we didn’t miss any other earlier candidates for that tag.

Above all, we keep the experience of the user in mind when proposing or creating a new tag, always asking: will the new tag allow users a more intuitive and efficient search of specific topics? If the team agrees that the new tag will be useful, the tag enters its trial or experimental phase. (You’ll see a few places on the schema that have yellow highlighting; these are the experimental tags currently under consideration.) During the experimental phase, our discussions focus primarily on tag clarity and definitional independence. In order to ensure clarity of the new definition, we test it against articles previously flagged as good candidates for the tag. If the new tag overlaps too much with the definition of other tags or does not include all scholarship related to the topic, we edit the new tag’s definition and test it again. The new tag will likely go through a few revisions because we aim to create a tag that fits the scholarship instead of describing only a fraction of scholarship that fits the tag.

This process is one of many that our team grapples with on a regular basis in the service of creating a truly useful tool for practitioners and researchers. I am very happy to talk more about processes and structural issues in the Q&A.

The undergraduate students, graduate students, librarians, Humanities Digital Workshop staff, and faculty who have been part of the GVD team have mapped the multidisciplinary landscape of gender violence as a field in an unprecedented way, helping to bridge the research/practice divide, and promoting access to research for practitioners and researchers alike.

Bibliography

  1. Brofenbrenner, Urie. “Toward an Experimental Ecology of Human Development.” American Psychologist, 32 (1977): 513–531.
  2. Evidence-Based Medicine Working Group. “A New Approach to Teaching the Practice of Medicine.” Journal of the American Medical Association 268 (1992): 2420–25.
  3. hooks, bell. Feminist Theory: From Margin to Center, 2nd edition. Cambridge, MA: South End Press, 1984.
  4. Mosley, Jennifer E., Nicole P. Marwell, and Marci Ybarra. “How the ‘What Works’ Movement is Failing Human Service Organizations, and What Social Work Can Do to Fix It.” Human Service Organizations: Management, Leadership & Governance (2019) (print forthcoming). https://doi.org/10.1080/23303131.2019.1672598
  5. Mullen, Edward J., Aron Shlonsky, Sarah E. Bledsoe, and Jennifer Bellamy. “From Concept to Implementation: Challenges Facing Evidence-Based Social Work.” Evidence and Policy: A Journal of Debate, Research, and Practice 1, no. 1 (2005): 61–84.
  6. Serrata, Josephine V., Martha Hernandez-Martinez, R. Lilliane Macias, Alvina Rosales, Rebecca Rodriguez, and Julia Perilla. “Expanding Evidence-Based Practice Models for Domestic Violence Initiatives: A Community-Centered Approach.” Psychology of Violence 7, no. 1 (2017): 158–165.
